attributes.title: The epidemiology or management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity or country of birth: A systematic review.

summary.value:
This is the registration for a systematic review of the epidemiology or management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity or country of birth. The protocol attached to this registration has been written in line with the PRISMA-P 2015 statement. This registration links to our OSF pre-registration (DOI: 10.17605/OSF.IO/R3U8E).

Rationale: 

Since the 1970’s there has been substantial emigration from the Pacific Islands to more developed countries, mainly New Zealand, Australia and the United States. While early migration reports migration as circular, it has since become more permanent and many Pacific Islanders are permanently emigrating from their islands (1). 

Most health information available homogenises Pacific people into one group, and much less has evaluated Pacific-specific health. The life expectancy of Pacific peoples is at least 6 years lower than that for all people living in New Zealand combined (2). CVD is the major cause of this difference, as (with diabetes) it is the major cause of amenable mortality among Pacific peoples. The amenable mortality rate from CVD among Pacific men is 2.5 times the rate of NZ men, and for Pacific women is 3.2 times the rate of NZ women (2). Despite overall reductions in the morbidity and mortality of CVD in New Zealand since the 1980s, Pacific peoples continue to experience a disproportionately high burden of CVD compared with Europeans (3). 

Pacific peoples are exposed to greater levels of CVD risk factors, such as smoking (men only), diabetes, diastolic blood pressure and ratios of total cholesterol to high density lipoprotein cholesterol (women only) (3). After adjusting for multiple established CVD risk factors, in addition to deprivation, 5-year risk of a first CVD event was approximately 20% higher for Pacific peoples compared with Europeans (4). Pacific peoples in New Zealand comprise a heterogeneous population who identify with at least one of 12 nations originating from the Pacific Islands of Polynesia, Melanesia and Micronesia (5).

As with other data reported in New Zealand, data on CVD generally combines Pacific peoples into a single category, despite important differences between Pacific peoples in CVD risk profiles (5). In addition to self-identified ethnicity, there are important differences between New Zealand-born and migrant Pacific peoples, particularly in terms of the duration of their exposure to the New Zealand physical and social environment (6). 

A recent health needs analysis of Pacific peoples in metro Auckland, in which 71% of the New Zealand Pacific population resides, assessed Pacific health in Pacific-specific subgroups (7). The analysis found that the prevalence of ischemic heart disease and peripheral vascular disease were significantly higher among Cook Island Maori than among other Pacific-specific subgroups (7). The prevalence of stroke was higher in Samoan people and lower in Tongan people, compared with the overall prevalence of stroke in Pacific peoples (7).

No known reviews of the epidemiology and management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to their Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth exist, despite evidence suggesting lower all-cause (and possibly cancer and CVD) mortality rates for Pacific migrants resident in NZ for less than 25 years relative to those resident for more than 25 years (8). Such information is critical to give important insight into access to cardiac services for Pacific people.

registration_responses.summary:
This is the registration for a systematic review of the epidemiology or management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to Pacific-specific ethnicity or country of birth. The protocol attached to this registration has been written in line with the PRISMA-P 2015 statement. This registration links to our OSF pre-registration (DOI: 10.17605/OSF.IO/R3U8E).

Rationale: 

Since the 1970’s there has been substantial emigration from the Pacific Islands to more developed countries, mainly New Zealand, Australia and the United States. While early migration reports migration as circular, it has since become more permanent and many Pacific Islanders are permanently emigrating from their islands (1). 

Most health information available homogenises Pacific people into one group, and much less has evaluated Pacific-specific health. The life expectancy of Pacific peoples is at least 6 years lower than that for all people living in New Zealand combined (2). CVD is the major cause of this difference, as (with diabetes) it is the major cause of amenable mortality among Pacific peoples. The amenable mortality rate from CVD among Pacific men is 2.5 times the rate of NZ men, and for Pacific women is 3.2 times the rate of NZ women (2). Despite overall reductions in the morbidity and mortality of CVD in New Zealand since the 1980s, Pacific peoples continue to experience a disproportionately high burden of CVD compared with Europeans (3).

After adjusting for multiple established CVD risk factors, in addition to deprivation, 5-year risk of a first CVD event was approximately 20% higher for Pacific peoples compared with Europeans (4). No known reviews of the epidemiology and management of cardiovascular disease among Pacific people according to their Pacific-specific ethnicity and country of birth exist, despite evidence suggesting lower all-cause (and possibly cancer and CVD) mortality rates for Pacific migrants resident in NZ for less than 25 years relative to those resident for more than 25 years (8). Such information is critical to give important insight into access to cardiac services for Pacific people.

attributes.title: Survey analysis
attributes.description: In this project, we analyze whether individuals are more likely to conduct genetic tests about their cancer risks and record their data, if the data remains private and the test is paid for by the health insurance.

q1.value: Effect of privacy and financing on willingness to conduct genetic tests.

q3.value: Although there are many surveys about factors determining the willingness to participate in genetic tests, there is limited evidence on whether individuals are more willing to do this if they know that their data remains their private property and if the test is paid for by the health insurance. We analyse this research gap through a survey experiment.

q4.value:
H1: If the health insurance pays for a genetic test to determine their cancer risk, individuals are more likely to conduct such as test.

H2: If they know that their data remains private, individuals are more likely to conduct a genetic test dtermining their cancer risk.

H3: The effects of H1 and H2 should reenforce one another.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: The study is a survey experiment where we ask the willingness to do tests. Between subjects design. 4 levels (Very unlikely, unlikely, likely, very likely).

q9.value: Done by the company conducting the survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants are recruited by the implementing company that conducts the survey.

q14.value: We limited the sample size to 1000 participants due to limited funds.

question.value: We manipulate the question about how data are stored and who will pay for genetic test.
We measure the probability to conduct a genetic test as well as blood tests and the use of applications to store health data.

We are planning to conduct regression models with treatment effects. We will include a battery of control variables about the respondents general attitudes regarding genetic tests, political attitudes, state of the individuals' health, health insurance plans as well as the personal situation of the household.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject answered each each question regarding genetic tests. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: Subjects that did not answer their willingness to conduct a genetic test will not be included.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits, political attitudes as well as health status may be related to the willingness to conduct a test. Therefore, we will look for relationships between these variables and the primary outcome measures of test participation willingness.

registration_responses.q3: Although there are many surveys about factors determining the willingness to participate in genetic tests, there is limited evidence on whether individuals are more willing to do this if they know that their data remains their private property and if the test is paid for by the health insurance. We analyse this research gap through a survey experiment.

H3: The effects of H1 and H2 should reenforce one another.

Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of task-shifting for the detection of diabetic retinopathy in low- and middle-income countries: a rapid review protocol.

q1.value: Effectiveness of task-shifting for the detection of diabetic retinopathy in low- and middle-income countries: a rapid review protocol.

q2.value: Covadonga Bascaran, Nyawira Mwangi, Fabrizio D'Esposito, Iris Gordon, Juan Alberto Lopez Ulloa, Shaffi Mdala, Jacqueline Ramke, Matthew Burton

q3.value: A key barrier to the implementation of screening services in low- and middle-income countries is the low number of ophthalmologists per million population. Interventions that shift screening to non-ophthalmology cadres have been implemented in programmes in low- and middle-income countries and are routinely used in high-income countries. This review aims to summarise the published literature reporting the effectiveness of such task-shifting interventions for the detection of diabetic retinopathy in LMICs by non-ophthalmologists.

q4.value: Task-shifting can improve detection rates of diabetic retinopathy (DR) among adults with diabetes in LMICs compared with eye examination done by ophthalmologists

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Rapid review of published evidence.In the absence of consensus at the time of this review, we used the STARR Decision Tool and the WHO practical guide to carefully consider the methods most appropriate for this review and the possible limitations introduced by those methods.
We will search MEDLINE, Embase, Global Health.The search strategies will be developed by the Cochrane Eyes and Vision Information Specialist (IG). Field experts will be provided a list of the included studies and requested to identify any additional studies. Grey literature will not be considered.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will limit the search to peer reviewed publications of community or facility-based primary studies conducted in LMICs that examine task-shifting interventions for DR detection delivered by non-ophthalmologists (community health workers, nurses, pharmacists, or any other allied health professionals), and report uptake of DR detection services, DR detection rates or detection accuracy. 
We will limit the searches to studies carried out in LMICs in the last 10 years and restrict to publications in the English language. We will include full reports of experimental studies (randomised controlled trials, cluster randomised trials, quasi experimental studies, and before-and-after designs), observational studies (prospective and retrospective cohorts) and diagnostic accuracy studies. Studies involving health education, training programmes or qualitative studies will be excluded.

Uptake of DR detection services 
DR Detection Rates
Accuracy of DR detection (sensitivity, specificity)
Severity of DR disease at detection (retinopathy grade)
Cost-effectiveness

Data will be summarized narratively to present the scope and nature of the evidence and no studies will be excluded on the basis of quality. We will follow the SWiM reporting guidance:  Synthesis Without Meta-analysis reporting items.

registration_responses.q1: Effectiveness of task-shifting for the detection of diabetic retinopathy in low- and middle-income countries: a rapid review protocol.
registration_responses.q2: Covadonga Bascaran, Nyawira Mwangi, Fabrizio D'Esposito, Iris Gordon, Juan Alberto Lopez Ulloa, Shaffi Mdala, Jacqueline Ramke, Matthew Burton

summary.value: This is the preregistration of Study 3 in the context of the project entitled "The Experience of Hate: a Multidimensional Exploratory Study on Hating Things, Individuals, and Groups (https://osf.io/pyza2/)". The aim of Study 3 is to extend the findings of the previous two studies by testing the differences between hate and anger, contempt and disgust. We will conduct three sub-studies, one for each emotion, employing full within-subjects designs. We will examine the relations between interpersonal and intergroup hate, and we will explore the structural relations and the variance accounted by the discrete emotions on a hate latent construct.

registration_responses.summary: This is the preregistration of Study 3 in the context of the project entitled "The Experience of Hate: a Multidimensional Exploratory Study on Hating Things, Individuals, and Groups (https://osf.io/pyza2/)". The aim of Study 3 is to extend the findings of the previous two studies by testing the differences between hate and anger, contempt and disgust. We will conduct three sub-studies, one for each emotion, employing full within-subjects designs. We will examine the relations between interpersonal and intergroup hate, and we will explore the structural relations and the variance accounted by the discrete emotions on a hate latent construct.

attributes.title: Disease Avoidance and Preferences for Leader Attractiveness Experiment
attributes.description: Disease Avoidance and Preferences for Leader Attractiveness Experiment

summary.value:
This is a partial conceptual replication of White et al. 2013: "Beauty at the Ballot Box: Disease Predict Preferences for Physically Attractive Leaders".

The data collection begins today (March 20, 2020) and runs during the peak of the Corona crisis in Denmark. The data collection will end in the final week of March. N=1700.

See attached document of details on hypothesis and data collection.

data.name: Pre-Analysis Plan for Diseas Avoidance and Leader Trait Pref Study FINAL.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Pre-Analysis Plan for Diseas Avoidance and Leader Trait Pref Study FINAL.docx

attributes.title: Exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19), anxiety, and social distance

q1.value: Exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19), anxiety level, and social distance towards foreign nationalities

q2.value: Michał Białek, Agata Groyecka, Maciej Karwowski, Marta Kowal, Izabela Lebuda, Agnieszka Sorokowska, Piotr Sorokowski, Przemysław Zdybek

q3.value: We intend to investigate how exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19) is associated with the social distance, and anxiety level

q4.value: Main hypothesis: The exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19) is positively related to social distance towards foreign nationalities and anxiety level

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Correlational and longitudinal design. 

Participants will keep a diary for two days. On the first day, participants will answer questions related to the exposition to Coronavirus (i.e., the time spent on searching for information about Coronavirus and time spent on talking about Coronavirus), and self-reported anxiety level (Day 1). The second part (on Day 2) will contain questions about the social distance towards foreign nationalities. 

In the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The decision to pre-register was taken a few hours after data collection had begun. Data collection is now in progress (Day 1), but the data collection has not been yet completed. The pre-registration is submitted before Day 2 measurements will occur.

question.value:
The study will be conducted online, among university students from two study sites: Warsaw and Wrocław (Poland).

In total, at least 170 participants will be recruited. Participants will not be compensated for their participation.

All participants will be invited to take part in two, seemingly unrelated studies, during two consecutive days. Only participants who provide written informed consent to participate will be invited to the study. On the first day, participants will be asked two questions about their exposition to Coronavirus: the time they spent on searching for information about Coronavirus, and the time they spent talking about Coronavirus (the duration estimated on a seven point Likert scale). Moreover, we will measure participants’ anxiety level (i.e. how much afraid, nervous, and alert they are feeling), using a seven point Likert scale. On the second day, we will measure participants’ social distance towards Hungarians, Mongols, Italians, Germans, Chinese, Jews, Russians, Poles, and Americans.

In the end, participants will provide information regarding basic socio-economic measures.

q14.value: Based on our intended mediation analysis and MedPower  (https://davidakenny.shinyapps.io/MedPower/), we determined the sample size based on the smallest effect size of interest (SESOI), that is: Exposition to Coronavirus -> Anxiety (a path) Beta = 0.25, Anxiety -> Distance toward other nationalities (b path), beta = .20 and Exposition to Coronavirus -> Distance (c path), beta = .20, with 80% power and one-tailed test. The sample size needed to estimate a path is n = 97, b path n = 153, c’ (direct) path n = 153, c (total) path n = 97 and ab path (indirect effect) N = 171. Thus, we intend to collect data from at least 180 participants.

question.value: No manipulation involved in the present study.

Exposition to Coronavirus
Participants will be asked two questions about their exposition to Coronavirus: the time they spent on searching for information about Coronavirus, and the time they spent talking about Coronavirus (the duration estimated on a seven-point Likert scale

Anxiety level
Participants will be asked about their anxiety level (i.e. how much afraid, nervous, and alert they are feeling), using a seven-point Likert scale. 

Social distance
We will measure participants’ social distance towards Hungarians, Mongols, Italians, Germans, Chinese, Jews, Russians, Poles, and Americans

We are going to examine the relationship between exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19) and anxiety level during Day 1 as well as regress Day 2 social distance towards foreign nationalities on Coronavirus exposition and anxiety from Day 1. We will test mediation model “exposition to Coronavirus -> anxiety -> social distance” for each of the nations included into the Study, as well as for the overall social distance measure, aggregated across nations (if such constructed scale will have the reliability > .70).

registration_responses.q1: Exposition to Coronavirus (COVID-19), anxiety level, and social distance towards foreign nationalities
registration_responses.q2: Michał Białek, Agata Groyecka, Maciej Karwowski, Marta Kowal, Izabela Lebuda, Agnieszka Sorokowska, Piotr Sorokowski, Przemysław Zdybek

The sample size needed to estimate a path is n = 97, b path n = 153, c’ (direct) path n = 153, c (total) path n = 97 and ab path (indirect effect) N = 171. Thus, we intend to collect data from at least 180 participants.
